texts.shortText:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This relatively small, slender and compressed species has an even dorsal fin of 35–41 spines and 2–3 rays, lacking either an anterior crest or notch (although the second spine may be slightly longer than the others). The cirri above the eyes are elongate and spoon-shaped, with lateral branches. Colour highly variable and often very attractive, commonly with broken brown or red vertical bars, and often with two large, dark spots on dorsal fin. There is generally a distinctive yellowish, dark-edged flare across the cheek and the eyes have a characteristic radiating pattern of alternating orange and green ‘spokes’.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.

A fairly common species usually found on rocky reefs below the intertidal and to a depth of about 30 m. The attractive and variable colour patterns and striking eye colour make this a photographer’s favourite, although the enormous variation in colour can make identification tricky.
Unusual in that the most common component of the diet is brittle stars, with amphipods, isopods, and other small crustaceans making up most of the remainder.

Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.

Colour variable, but most specimens can be recognised by the unusual green and orange spoked colour of the eyes, the flash across the cheek and the two large spots on the dorsal fin. The spoon-like cirri above the eyes with their marginal branches also a good identification feature.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 328).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 399).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 765).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 64).
